title.text: Proceedings of the 2nd Workshop on Computational Linguistics and Clinical Psychology: From Linguistic Signal

introductionContent.text: The 2015 ACL Workshop on Computational Linguistics and Clinical Psychology included a shared task focusing on classification of a sample of Twitter users according to three mental health categories: users who have self-reported a diagnosis of depression, users who have self-reported a diagnosis of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), and control users who have done neither).

entities.text: 2015 ACL Workshop on Computational Linguistics and Clinical Psychology

introductionContent.text: Like other shared tasks, the goal here was to assess the state of the art with regard to a challenging problem, to advance that state of the art, and to bring together and hopefully expand the community of researchers interested in solving it.
The core problem under consideration here is the identification of individuals who suffer from mental health disorders on the basis of their online language use.

As noted in their introduction to the first ACL Workshop on Computational Linguistics and Clinical Psychology, few social problems are more costly than problems of mental health, in every possible sense of cost, and identifying people who need help is a huge challenge fora variety of reasons, including the fear of social or professional stigma, an inability of people to recognize symptoms and report them accurately, and the lack of access to clinicians.

entities.text: ACL Workshop on Computational Linguistics and Clinical Psychology

introductionContent.text: Language technology has the potential to make areal difference by offering low-cost, unintrusive methods for early screening, i.e. to identify people who should be more thoroughly evaluated by a professional, and for ongoing monitoring, i.e. to help providers serve their patients better over the long-term continuum of care ().
This paper summarizes the University of Maryland contribution to the CLPsych 2015 shared task.
More details of our approach appear in, where we also report results on preliminary experimentation using the CLPsych Hackathon data).
